intro: Echeandia terniflora, commonly known as the three-leaved cactus, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of South America. It belongs to the family Cactaceae and is characterized by its spiny stems and clusters of small, yellow flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky soils and can withstand extreme drought conditions. Its leaves are reduced to spines, and it produces small, fleshy fruits that are edible. Echeandia terniflora plays a role in local ecosystems by providing food and shelter for various desert animals.
